title: Map the data ecosystem (steps 2, 3, 4)
body:
Data ecosystems consist of the organisations, communities and people that create and benefit from the value created by the data flowing through our data infrastructure. Before publishing anonymised data it is important to map your own data ecosystem. This can help your organisation identify the key data stewards and users within your ecosystem, the relationships between them and the different roles they play. 

This module explains:

  • What is a data ecosystem
  • Why is it important for anonymisation
  • How to construct your data ecosystem map

title: Sample Ethics Canvas Questions
instruction: Below is a sample of some of the the Data Ethics Canvas

_items.title: Sharing data with other organisations
_items.body: Are you going to be sharing data with other organisations? If so, who? Are you planning to publish any of the data? Under what conditions?

_items.title: Your reasons for using this data
_items.body: What is your primary purpose for collecting and using data in this project? What are the main use case/s, and your business model? Are you making things better for society? How? For whom?

_items.title: Positive effects on people
_items.body: Which individuals, groups, demographics or organisations will be positively affected by this project? How will they be positively affected? How are you measuring and communicating positive impact?

_items.title: Openness and transparency
_items.body: How open can you be about this project? Could you publish your methodology, metadata, datasets, code or impact measurements? Can you ask peers to give feedback on the project? How will you communicate about it internally?

_items.title: Reviews and iterations
_items.body: How will ongoing issues related to data ethics be measured, monitored, discussed, and actioned?

_items.title: GDPR
_items.body: The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) came into force in May 2018 and governs the processing of personal data the free movement of personal data for within the European Union and for EU citizens generally. Anonymised data is not considered in scope for GDPR, but personal data before anonymisation is.

_graphic.attribution: London Market Group [All rights reserved]

_items.title: GDPR and national legislation
_items.body: The application of GDPR varies from one country to another: in the UK, the 2018 Data Protection Act implements and extends GDPR.

_graphic.attribution: London Market Group [All rights reserved]

_items.title: Talk to your DPO and legal team
_items.body: Most organisations will be required by GDPR to appoint a Data Protection Officer. Your DPO may be able to help you understand and navigate your legal context and requirements. If in doubt, talk to your legal team.

title: The Data Spectrum
body:
The ODI’s Data Spectrum describes the different levels at which data be closed or open. It ranges from closed, highly restricted-access, data to open data that can be accessed and used by anyone for any purpose. 

The Data Spectrum can be used to think about the level of anonymisation needed for the project. The more open (and further to the right) the data is on the spectrum, the greater the level of anonymisation will need to be applied to the data. If the data has group-based access then we have a better idea of who is using it, what the re-identification risks are and what are the uses of the data. However, in open data with many more users, the risks become greater and we’ll need to increase the anonymisation applied to the data.

title: Next Steps
body: The situation, and risks, will evolve over time. Plan how you will deal with changes, be prepared in case something goes wrong, and more generally actively maintain trust in your management of risk.

_graphic.attribution: London Market Group [All rights reserved]
London Market Group [All rights reserved]

_items.title: Analysing Passenger’s Journey Times
_items.body:
A public transport company wants to open its travel data to the public for research and commercial use. However, they want to remove personal geolocation data. With generalisation of ages, hashing of travel card numbers, we can release this data being much more confident that individuals can’t be re-identified. 

TODO: Add dataset as image

_items.title: Accident & Emergency Admittance Data
_items.body:
A health service want to release A&E data for use by health researchers to study treatment times around the country. However, they want to keep this very sensitive health data private. By focusing on the specific use case they decided to suppress patient IDs, hospital names, and arrival dates. They then generalised the postcode in to area codes and the times in to 4-hour blocks. 

TODO: add dataset as image

_graphic.attribution: London Market Group [All rights reserved]

_items.title: Work with others
_items.body: Thinking through risk scenarios is extremely difficult to do alone. As the data steward and the person planning to process or share data, you may have blind spots preventing you from effectively thinking about what might go wrong.

_items.title: Mapping data flows
_items.body:
In our exercise on A&E data, we used the ODI’s Data Ecosystem Map to get a view of all the actors in the flow of data - including people who may never see the data in any shape or form but are impacted by the ecosystem of insights, products or services the data may enable. This is a good way to think of people or organisations which may be impacted by the risk, or who may be the root of the risk.

[use image: synAE ecosystem map on Kumu]

_items.title: Using the data spectrum
_items.body:
Mapping a whole data ecosystem may yield a very long list of actors, which in turn should all be considered as potential adversaries or impacted by the risk scenarios. As a way to speed up the process, using the data spectrum to think about the governance and ease of access to the data may help you draw groups of actors in similar situations. In the health service case, we identified a group of organisations likely to use the anonymised open data, but who also had access to related data through separate data sharing agreements. We were able to think of risks and scenarios for this group as a whole.

[use image: data spectrum]

Read more on this threat modelling exercise.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

_items.title: Data controllers and processors
_items.body:
GDPR and other regulations make an important distinction between data controller, the actors(s) determining the manner in which, and the purposes for which, the data are processed, and data processors, who processes the data on behalf of the data controller. Overall responsibility for the data lies with the data controllers, while data processors are mostly held accountable through contract and agreements. 

More info at the ICO

_graphic.attribution: London Market Group [All rights reserved]

_items.title: Use your data ecosystem map
_items.body: Data protection legislation will largely concern itself with data flows (including how the data came to be under your stewardship) and actors (data subjects, data controllers and data processors). The data ecosystem map you created in earlier steps should give you a good picture of both.

_graphic.attribution: London Market Group [All rights reserved]

title: Why is Data Ecosystem Mapping important?
displayTitle: Why is Data Ecosystem Mapping important?
body:
Data ecosystem maps can make it easier to explain the ecosystems that exist around products and services. They are particularly useful when contexts are complex, not well understood or not yet fully developed. 

When finished, the map is valuable as a communication tool to support engagement across the data ecosystem. In addition, there is value to be gained from the process of drawing it. Mapping requires you to consider different actors, relationships and ideas in the system, and can generate useful insights and talking points. 

In the context of anonymisation, it is possible to build upon a data ecosystem map to identify where in your ecosystem anonymisation processes will occur and where data will exist in anonymised and non-anonymised states. This can further help your organisation think about potential threats and benefits to the organisations, communities and people within your ecosystem.

title: Data Protection Impact Assessment
body:
The ICO defines a Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA) as a process to help you identify and minimise the data protection risks of a project. You must do a DPIA for processing that is likely to result in a high risk to individuals.

(Use image?: https://ico.org.uk/media/2258436/dpia1.png) 

You do not have to create your DPIA process from scratch. The ICO offers guidance and templates, and you may find examples of how others in your sector or domain have done it.

Examples in:

  • Academia: Donor research using public information 
  • Public Sector: Community Wellbeing Centre (Local council) 
  • Third Sector: National Neonatal Audit Programme (UK Charity)

title: What is a use case?
body:
A use case is a method to describe who will be using your system and what they will be using it for. It identifies typical users, what they’re trying to achieve, what environments they’ll be in and what systems they’ll use. Creating use cases helps keep users goals as a primary focus when designing a system.

For anonymisation, your use cases provide context on how to release your data and what form the data should take. If you understand that some users want access to a particular variable you consider risky, you may need to restrict who has access to that data. To meet your obligations to release safe, useful data you may also share it with a wider audience under a different licence by restricting a lot of the detail.

For example the Wealth and Asset Survey looks at personal financial information. These variables are usually anonymised or even omitted. But in this case they are the core variables, so the anonymisation methods focus on other information like demographics.

See also: UK Government design principles.

_graphic.attribution: London Market Group [All rights reserved]

title: Risk scenarios
body: There are several types of risk associated with an anonymisation project. The most obvious may be re-identification – the possibility that a person may be identified in the data, and private information learned about them. There are however many others.

_items.title: Data breach
_items.body: Consider what may happen if data is shared anonymously, but the security of the data kept pre-anonymisation is insufficient, leading to the breach of private information.

_items.title: Misidentification
_items.body: A type of scenario where individuals are not identifiable in the data, but an "educated guess" can be made as to the identity of the person whose data is anonymised. Drawing the wrong conclusions from the data can be just as harmful as learning private information about people

_items.title: Membership attack
_items.body: Breaking anonymisation is not simply a matter of looking at the data and guessing who might be behind it. Frequent cases of re-identification or breaches of anonymisation start by knowing information about someone who may be represented in the data, checking if they are, and then trying to learn something new about them

title: How to build your Data Ecosystem Map

_items.title: Identify the main categories of actors in the ecosystem
_items.body: Before beginning the process of constructing your map, it can be helpful to define a list of actors and data flows within your ecosystem. Common roles include: data stewards, regulators, intermediaries, creators (or resusers of data), beneficiaries and policymakers.

_items.title: Map the data flows between actors
_items.body: Once you have identified the main actors in your ecosystem, you can begin drawing the ecosystem on a whiteboard or on post-it notes. Starting with a single organisation you can draw lines and arrows between actors to represent the various data flows within the system. It is often helpful to start with the area of the ecosystem that you know best and to expand out from there. As you fill out your ecosystem, be careful to identify organisations performing anonymisation processes and to differentiate between arrows representing anonymised data versus non-anonymised data.

_items.title: Map the exchanges of tangible and intangible value
_items.body: After mapping the data flows between actors you can then draw lines and arrows to represent any exchanges of tangible and intangible value within the system. Examples of exchanges of tangible value include physical goods, money, services provided and any charges for those services. Common examples of intangible value include exchanges of knowledge, feedback, insights, support or policy advice.

_items.title: Identify any potential benefits or threats to actors within the system
_items.body: Now that you have a working map of the various actors in your ecosystem, the data flows and the tangible and intangible value exchanged between actors you can use the map to identify [vulnerabilities, bottlenecks or security threats] and [guide conversations] about potential benefits and harms to the organisations, communities and people within your ecosystem.
_items.strapline: Identify any potential benefits or threats to actors within the system

title: The Data Ethics Canvas
body: The ODI’s Data Ethics Canvas is designed to help identify potential ethical issues associated with a data project or activity. This helps the people anonymising and opening the data to have early discussions beyond basic legal compliance and think about the moral implications of holding or withholding all or certain parts of the data.

title: Map the legal issues (step 5)
body:
Legislation and regulation can impede, allow or even impel the flow of data. It is crucial to understand the legal context and obligations before proceeding any further. 

This module explains:

  • What are the legal issues to consider
  • Data Protection Impact Assessments
  • What next

title: Why is it important to describe the use case?
displayTitle: Why is it important to describe the use case?
body: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. _graphic.attribution: London Market Group [All rights reserved]

title: What is a Data Ecosystem Map?
displayTitle: What is a Data Ecosystem Map?
body: A data ecosystem map illustrates the value exchanges in an ecosystem. Drawing on ideas from rich picturing, systems thinking and value network analysis, data ecosystem mapping can help your organisation create a visual map that [illustrates] how data is being accessed, used and shared by a variety of organisations.

title: Describe the use case (step 1)
body:
This module explains:

  • What is a use case
  • Why it’s important to know what to keep in your data and what to remove
  • How to describe your use case and understand your users with:
    • User Research Tools
    • Data Ethics Canvas
    • Data Spectrum

title: Some user research methods
body: Below is just a small sample of user research methods that exist. Which ones to use can depend on the type of project, resources available or type of users. See more at usability.gov user research methods.

_items.title: User Interviews
_items.body: One-on-one interviews with users to understand their particular needs. These usually involve transcribing the interviews and finding important patterns among the multiple interviews. These are usually conducted at the beginning of project to get early insights in to the users and what they hope to achieve with the product.

_items.title: User Personas
_items.body: These are fictional characters representing a particular group of users who are similar in attitudes, goals and behaviours. In creating good user personas, you hope to increase empathy and understanding of each group’s needs and design your system accordingly.

_items.title: Usability testing
_items.body: Users are asked to complete certain tasks while being observed by a researcher. The researcher notes whether the tasks can be completed easily and if there was any confusion performing them. For anonymisation, you could ask some of the following. Iis the dataset clearly presented, accessible, and well-described? Do they understand the difference between the original data and the de-identified data and how utility may be affected? Can users still gather the insights they are looking for?

title: Monitor the data situation
body:
The data situation you have evaluated, and the risks you have assessed and worked to mitigate, may change over time. New technology may be created or made easier to access, other data may be made available, new actors may come into the ecosystem. 

Putting in place mechanisms to review and monitor changes in the data situation, so you can revise your risk management processes accordingly. The Anonymisation Decision making framework recommends that you:

  1. Keep a register of all the data you have shared or released - and keep those in mind whenever going through the process, especially looking out for linkage risks
  2. If possible, keep track of how the data you shared or released is used
  3. Review the whole process (steps 1-9) frequently
  4. Keep track of all the changes, and assess whether changes require a complete case review.
  5. Put in place a policy for carrying out that monitoring with clear lines of responsibility.

_graphic.attribution: London Market Group [All rights reserved]
Reisnl, Gantz, Rydning, Klein [CC0]

_items.title: Breach management and notification
_items.body: When a breach happens, your main objective will be to contain it as well as possible, but it is only the beginning of breach management. The process you should put in place and follow in case of a breach should also include steps - and clear responsibility - for assessing and dealing with any ongoing risk, notification of a breach to stakeholders (including the ICO), and review and learning lessons.

_items.title: Communication
_items.body: Make sure your crisis management plan includes a strategy for communicating with stakeholder, especially those who may potentially be directly affected by the breach, the ICO, the media and other interested parties. Transparency is always preferable but you will probably need time to get all the key information together so you may need an initial holding response to stakeholders such as ‘we are investigating the matter

_items.title: Review
_items.body: A crucial part of your crisis plan involves how you will learn lessons from the event and put procedures in place to prevent a further occurrence. You should stipulate who will undertake the review and within what time frame.

title: Identify the processes you will need to control disclosure risk
displayTitle: Identify the processes you will need to control disclosure risk
body:
Choosing the right anonymisation methods depends on your specific data situation. This will involve surveying the available techniques in two areas. 

Firstly, control. How to make sure unwanted people can’t access personal information? Do you simply remove names? Do you only share the data under a licence? Do you use differential privacy?

Secondly, assessment. What are your test mechanisms to ensure you have the right balance between utility and risk in the data? User interviews? Penetration testing? Correlation analysis?

To do these, you’ll need to have a good understanding of what is and is not personal data and range anonymisation techniques out there.  

In this module you’ll:

  • How to recognise personal data you may need to anonymise
  • Examples of anonymisation 
  • An overview of the 3 main anonymisation methods

_items.title: Suppression
_items.body: This is the deletion of values, be it entire records or attributes that directly identify people. For instance, removing a Name column or a certain rows’ Address value. The effectiveness of suppression depends on who the data is released to and what other possible linking datasets they may have access to.

_items.title: Disruption
_items.body: Where a small amount of random noise is added to individual attributes prior to publication. This means the attributes will be less accurate on a small or individual scale but across the entire dataset the overall patterns. For instance, if we added or subtracted up to 10cm from a dataset of people’s heights. We couldn’t be sure of any one person’s height, but be confident that the mean and variance were realistic.

_items.title: Generalisation
_items.body: Changing the scale or order of the value. By making data less precise, generalisation hopes to strike a balance between full-on suppression of values and low-level disruption. Examples of this would be putting in a salary range for individuals instead of an exact number, or for a birth date only leaving in the year. As the range is made large the privacy of the variable increases but the utility decreases.

title: Spot the personal data
body:
Accident & Emergency Admittance Data

 

Health service ID, Hospital, Arrival Time, Time in A&E (mins), Treatment, Gender, Age, Postcode

 

For a more in-depth guide to personal data, please see the ICO’s Determining what is personal data? report.

_items.title: Data consumers
_items.body: The people who are using the data. Engagement with them will be focused on their use cases and how you are maintaining access to the data. Also helping them understand the importance in protecting people’s personal data even at the risk of limiting their analyses.

_graphic.attribution: London Market Group [All rights reserved]

_items.title: Data Providers
_items.body: Who is providing the data to you. They’ll care about questions such as who has access to the original data? Who has access to the de-identified data? What other datasets are combined together? How do we ensure data subjects privacy? What infrastructure are you using to store and share the data?

_graphic.attribution: London Market Group [All rights reserved]

_items.title: Data Subjects
_items.body: The people who are represented in the data. They will likely be the largest and most disperse group. As such, one of the challenges will be communicating widely and concisely about the complexities of anonymisation and sharing data.  They’ll need to understand, at some level, about de-identification of data, the security of the original data, and the sharing of de-identified data.

_graphic.attribution: London Market Group [All rights reserved]

_items.title: Internal Managers
_items.body: Certain decision-makers within your organisation will need to kept informed about the project. This could be legal, management, or communication teams. While you mightn’t directly answer to some of them, their voices will be used to judge whether the project is worth undertaking and continuing. They’ll also be worried about reputational or legal damage to the organisation should the project go wrong.

title: What does “data situation” mean?
body:
The data situation is the relationship between data and its environment. 

Risk does not inherently lie in the data, nor in the environment, but in the data situation. For example, sharing data may only be risky if you share it with people who have access to related datasets, increasing the risks of linkage.

title: Health Service Case Study
body:
A health service wants to open up some of its A&E data to encourage transparency and to help researchers, government and the public improve the service. 

They know that health data can contain extremely sensitive information about people. However, they also believe the advantages to the health service could be great. They decide to release a set of A&E data that has gone through a significant de-identification process. To do this, they must engage with a set of important stakeholders and ask them certain questions. 

Here are just some of the questions they could ask of of the stakeholders.

Health Researchers: What insights are they trying to find out? What are some crucial variables to keep in the data? How do they want the data presented? Do they understand the importance of anonymising the data? 

A&E Patients: Do they know their data is being collected at all? What is the best way to inform possibly millions of people the ? How do you communicate best to the public at large? Using what media? How do you avoid people becoming distrustful of the health service? How can they find out more information on the project?

Health Watchdogs: Do the understand the technical difference between the original data and the anonymised data? What will convince them that the released data is sufficiently secure? How do they want the anonymisation process documented? 

Health Service Management: What departments and teams should be involved? What are their concerns about what could go wrong with the project? How often will you be in communication with them? Could some of them shut down the project?

title: Enagage with stakeholders (step 6)
body: That your stakeholders believe you are a trustworthy steward of the data, and that you understand the data’s risks and benefits, is important for the success of the project. Bad communication can lead to public mistrust, false insights and even project shutdown. While clear, empathic and continuous engagement can not only reduce misunderstanding but help the release of your dataset and increase its impact.

title: Understanding and managing risk
body:
Anonymisation is about managing risk. It is not about removing all risk, but about taking precautions. When anonymisation is done well the risk of disclosing information referring to individuals should be negligible.

At the heart of risk evaluation is usually an exercise to determine what scenarios could lead to harm, and then assess both how likely each scenario may be, and how harmful would its consequences be. Combining likelihood and severity, while not a precise measure, is usually considered a good proxy for assessing risk.
